Award.AwardTitle: Stable Assignment Problems for Staffing: Complete Matchings, Local Stability, and Dynamic Reassignments

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Assigning personnel to jobs is a large-scale problem faced by many organizations including the military and multinational organizations, such as United Nations agencies. Although successful algorithms have been developed that can ensure stable matchings (matchings without incentive to deviate), not all practical concerns have been addressed by these algorithms. This research was initiated by ongoing discussions with the World Food Programme (WFP), the largest humanitarian agency in the world. The humanitarian impact alone is significant, since stable matches lead to improved workforce stability, reduced costs of personnel assignments, and ultimately more dollars that can be used for beneficiaries. Findings of this research also have the potential to improve staff rotations in the US military, medical resident assignments, school choice, and organ allocations.

This research exploits aspects appearing in practical stable matching problems: (i) centralized organizations often can negotiate with specific agents to change their preference lists; (ii) for large systems not all staff or jobs will have complete knowledge of others' preference lists, hence potentially some stability considerations can be relaxed without introducing incentive issues. The objective of the proposed research is to develop mathematical models that can ensure a complete set of matchings even when preference lists are truncated, where the models are scalable for large organizations, and the algorithms provide approaches to make dynamic assignments over time. The proposed research will result in innovative models, algorithms, and approaches to solve large-scale assignment problems with considerations of user behavior. The methodologies to solve the problems include integer programming with equilibrium constraints, relaxation techniques, dynamic programming, and local search. The proposed research contributes to the intersection of computer science, economics and optimization, by studying optimization with decentralized decision makers in the context of developing algorithmic approaches to large-scale and practical stable matching problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied the assignment and reassignment of personnel to jobs, which is a large-scale problem faced by many organizations including the military, multi-national non-profits such as UN agencies, medical organizations, and others. Algorithms have been developed that can ensure staffing solutions that are stable without incentive to deviate, but they do not address many practical considerations including complete matches for large systems, adjusted fairness definition for periodic markets, centralized utility, or dynamic matches over time.

The research in this project developed models and algorithms that allowed for a complete and stable matching of jobs and personnel using mechanisms such as negotiations. For matchings over time, we developed mathematical models that captured the trade-offs between stability, fairness, and sustainability with negotiations. We examined the performance of the algorithms and objective functions when preferences were correlated, which illustrated insights useful for practice.

In terms of intellectual merit, this study contributed to a better understanding of matching markets (e.g., jobs and personnel), especially when matches are incomplete, matches need to be made over time, preferences are correlated, or negotiations can be used to affect preferences.  The research also contributed to a better understanding of different types of utility functions, and the relative trade-off between other performance measures such as stability, fairness, and sustainability.

In terms of broader impact, the work was applied to two specific case studies, including one with the US Airforce (USAF) and a second with the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP). The case study with USAF focused on assignments on a large network of 450,000 enlisted personnel and officers to duty positions.  It additionally informed the construction of preference lists that can be used to find a matching, aiding offers in listing additional options. The case study with WFP focused on solving a problem that typically takes a process of approximately 6 months and the resources of numerous personnel involved in the decision making. The problem solved using our methods addressed matching 462 staff to 365 open positons, which is a typical size of the personnel decisions that WFP makes 2-4 times a year. Our algorithms solved the matching problem in a few minutes with substantially the same quality of assignments or better to the existing 6 month process. We are currently in the process of implementing our algorithm at WFP for testing in their next cycle of assignments in early 2019. Currently, we are initiating a case study at the Coast Guard Academy for matching students to summer rotations on sea vessels. In addition to these examples of the application of the work to practice, we performed training of three graduate students and professional development opportunities, and several of the researchers involved include underrepresented minorities in engineering.  Finally, the work is being disseminated to the broader scientific community and incorporated into classrooms.
